May 8, 2011: Fiction
THE SIXTH MAN, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) The lawyer for an
alleged serial killer is murdered, and two former Secret Service agents are on the
case.
THE LAND OF PAINTED CAVES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $30.) The latest
volume in a series that began with “The Clan of the Cave Bear,” set during the ice
age.
THE FIFTH WITNESS, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) The defense
lawyer Mickey Haller represents a woman facing home foreclosure who is
accused of killing a banker.
CHASING FIRE, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $27.95.) A smoke jumper faces a
new season of firefighting in Montana after the loss of her partner.
I'LL WALK ALONE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.99.) A woman
haunted by the disappearance of her young son discovers that someone has
stolen her identity.
QUICKSILVER, by Amanda Quick. (Putnam, $25.95.) In this Arcane Society novel
set in Victorian London, two paranormal talents must find a murderer before they
become the next victims.
EVE, by Iris Johansen. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) The forensic sculptor Eve Duncan
searches for answers to the mystery of her daughter’s disappearance.
SAVE ME, by Lisa Scottoline. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) A mother’s action during a
school emergency causes an uproar in a Philadelphia suburb.
THE PRIEST'S GRAVEYARD, by Ted Dekker. (Center Street, $24.99.) A priest
and a young woman cross paths as they seek to bring a powerful man to justice.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of the Millennium trilogy, about a Swedish hacker and a
journalist.
44 CHARLES STREET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $28.) The owner of a
Greenwich Village town house takes in boarders and bonds with her tenants.
THE PALE KING, by David Foster Wallace. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) In this
unfinished novel, Wallace explores the innards of the Internal Revenue Service,
the value of work and the meaning of heroism.
SING YOU HOME, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $28.) Picoult takes on the issue of gay
rights in this novel about a music therapist who desperately wants a child; CD of
songs included.
Non-Fiction
BOSSYPANTS, by Tina Fey. (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown, $26.99.) A memoir
from the creator of "30 Rock."
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
LIBERTY DEFINED, by Ron Paul. (Grand Central, $24.99.) The Texas
congressman examines 50 controversial issues.
SHE WALKS IN BEAUTY, selected and introduced by Caroline Kennedy.
(Voice/Hyperion, $24.99.) Poems that inspired the former first daughter.
I'M OVER ALL THAT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Atria, $22.) The actress offers
observations on what remains important to her.
63 DOCUMENTS THE GOVERNMENT DOESN'T WANT YOU TO READ, by
Jesse Ventura with Dick Russell. (Skyhorse, $24.95.) The former governor of
Minnesota implores Americans to challenge government secrecy.
THE SOCIAL ANIMAL, by David Brooks. (Random House, $27.) Brooks creates
two imaginary people, Harold and Erica, to illustrate his understanding of the
human mind, the wellsprings of action and the causes of success and failure.
ALL THAT IS BITTER AND SWEET, by Ashley Judd with Maryanne Vollers.
(Ballantine, $26.) A memoir by the actress and humanitarian.
ONWARD, by Howard Schultz with Joanne Gordon. (Rodale, $25.99.) Schultz
tells of his second stint as the C.E.O. of Starbucks and how he helped return the
company to profitability.
IDEA MAN, by Paul Allen. (Portfolio/Penguin, $27.95.) The co-founder of Microsoft
details the early years of the software giant and his relationship with Bill Gates.
THE EMPEROR OF ALL MALADIES, by Siddhartha Mukherjee. (Scribner, $30.)
An oncologist's history of cancer.
BLOOD, BONES, AND BUTTER, by Gabrielle Hamilton. (Random House, $26.) A
memoir by the chef and owner of the Manhattan restaurant Prune.
MALCOLM X, by Manning Marable. (Viking, $30.) A biography of Malcolm X that
traces a path from his troubled youth to his conversion to Islam to his
assassination in 1965.
RIGHTEOUS INDIGNATION, by Andrew Breitbart. (Grand Central, $27.99.) The
commentator and Web entrepreneur charts his path from “cultural liberal” to
“conservative cultural warrior.”
